newsitem.title: USA: AT&T signs $43 mln pact with Kmart.
newsitem.headline: AT&T signs $43 mln pact with Kmart.

text.p: AT&T Corp said Monday it had signed a four-year contract worth $43 million to provide Kmart Corp with upgraded voice and data telecommunication services, replacing services provided by MCI Communications Corp.
Kmart expects to save more than $4.5 million in voice communications expenses over the life of the contract, AT&T said.

Under the agreement, AT&T will upgrade Kmart's existing data network with its Frame Relay service, as well as provide long distance and toll-free voice services to link the giant retailer's stores, headquarters and distribution facilities. Migration of voice servies to AT&T is expected to be complete in 90 days and transfer of data services will be complete by the end of 1998, AT&T said.
In a separate agrement, AT&T and Kmart will develop a co-branded employee discount card that can double as an AT&T calling card.

The cards will be issued to Kmart's 275,000 employees to be used to receive their 10 percent discount on certain items which they purchase at Kmart stores. The AT&T Calling Card feature can be used by Kmart employees to make calls away from home.
The agreement also enables Kmart employees to enroll in a new AT&T/Kmart residential long distance program, which will be introduced to employees by mid-1997.
